bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to William Crawford Gorgas, October 24, 1917

div1.p: Kean describes disagreements within the command of the Ambulance Corps on how to organize the ambulance service in France.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to William Crawford Gorgas, October 24, 1917
div1.opener:
699
file
France - 24 October 1917
My dear General Gorgas:
div1.p: I sent you a personal cable on October 7 as follows:

My reason for so doing was that apparently Captain Doyle constituted himself
an “officier de liaison” between the Ambulance Service with the French Army
and your office, and many of his ideas as expressed in letters and cables
which he has been sending to Major Andrew are not at all in accordance with
the interests of the service. His idea of making this a “lame duck” service
and sending here the physically unfit which have been rejected for service
with the National Army, and who could make use of their infirmities to get
out of the service whenever they chose, is, I think, particularly objection-
able. As long as we have such an enormous reserve of ablebodied men to draw
from, I do not see why the Ambulance Service should be handicapped by accept-
ing the physically unfit. Also, I know of no authorization from the War De-
partment to waive absolute disabilities.

Although I requested Major Andrew early in September to cable to Mr.
Sleeper that we did not want any more volunteers sent over for enlistment
here, but preferred trained men from Allentown, Mr. Sleeper has continued to
send men on nearly every boat. Many of these are physically unfit, and after
having incurred the heavy expense of buying uniforms and paying their own
transportation across the ocean, besides exposing themselves to the danger
of ocean travel at the present time, have the disappointment of being rejected
here. Those who are accepted are entirely untrained and therefore much less
desirable than the Allentown men which you have promised to send me to fill
up vacancies. Twenty (20) of these men arrived yesterday, and I understand
more are expected in 3 or 4 days. Nearly half of the last group were physi-
cally unfit. Colonel Birmingham tells me that about the 10th of September
he told Captain Doyle not to send any more men over without physical examina-
tion and enlistment, and that Captain Doyle promised that these instructions
would be carried out.

On October 9 I got General Pershing to cable asking that the State De-
partment be requested to refuse passports for all men coming here for enlist-
ment in the Ambulance Service. I hope that you will see that this is done.

4. Another matter about which there has been cable correspondence be-
tween Captain Doyle and Major Andrew is the question of taking over the two
American Field Service sections at Salonique. I have told Major Andrew that
of course if the War Department authorized their taking over I would adminis-
ter them. I think, however, that in view of the fact that we have not a single
commissioned officer with that army the matter of administration would occasion
an amount of trouble and expense altogether out of proportion to the benefit
conferred. The difficulties of communication and administration, which are
certainly abundant enough here, would be much greater from Salonique. I have
2-- General Gorgas - 26 Oct. 1917
therefore repeatedly recommended to Major Andrew that he turn over these
units to the Red Cross, which has officials on the ground and has the money
to administer the units. There does not seem to be any valid objection to
this, but I do not think that he is going to do it.

5. I have asked the Chief Surgeon's Office to send a cable asking
that the names of the officers above the grade of Captain in the Ambulance
Service be sent to me by cable and the Captains and Lieutenants by mail.
I am really a good deal at sea in the matter. I presume Colonel Persons is
the Colonel, and he wrote Birmingham under date of September 20 that Major
Hallett had been given one of the Lieutenant Colonelcies and he had recom-
mended Major Franklin for the other. In your letter to me of August 10
you state/that you had taken steps to fill these positions, and that I should
take steps to fill the other places. I assume that these other places refers
to any vacancies existing or that may occur in the 49 units authorized for
France and the 30 which have been ordered here, from Allentown. I would be
glad to have you give instructions to the Personnel Division looking to
these positions being filled only on my recommendation. There is a good deal
of jealousy between the three component parts of my command, and I am trying to
get up a system of selection for promotions which will get the best men. One
element of this will be graduation at the French transportation school at
Meaux. I am emphasizing this matter because there have been a number of pro-
motions made from the S. G. O. recently in the sections under my command.
I have no complaint to make of the selections, but would much prefer to have
the promise of your letter of August 10 carried out.

6. Colonel Persons mentions that Major Wrightson has been given the
supervision of the Ambulance Service in the Office. I am glad to hear it
because I will feel that I can get somebody who will answer letters. This
is not intended as a reflection on you, as I know how overwhelmed with work
you are and all I ask from you is that you will read my letters and then
refer them to Major Wrightson or whoever will handle them.

7. Birmingham's visit has been a great pleasure to us all. He is with
me now and leaves for the French front on Sunday. His promotion gave me the
sincerest pleasure, and I believe it had the universal approval of every man
in the corps. I believe that he will take back with him a great deal of very
valuable information which will be of much assistance in enabling the Office
to meet the needs of the service in Europe.

Can't you order my good friend Furbush to write me a letter and give
me some of the news of the Office. There is a rumor that legislation was
passed on October 5 which was of great importance to the Medical Corps, but
none of us has the faintest idea as to what it was, as yet. In fact, it is
hard to realize the isolation of our life from affairs in the United States.

With cordial good wishes to Furbush, Goodwin, Noble and my other friends
in the Office, I am,
